keyTakeAways: Mark Zuckerberg, founder of Facebook and CEO of Meta Platforms, is required to testify in a landmark trial over the impact of social media on young people.
Evan Spiegel, CEO of Snap, and Adam Mosseri, head of Instagram (a Meta-owned platform), are also ordered to testify, emphasizing the scope of executive accountability.
The trial, set for January 2025, is among the first major legal actions to address allegations that social media companies designed addictive features and failed to protect youth mental health.

The case consolidates hundreds of claims from parents and school districts alleging ineffective parental controls, lack of safety features, and the use of notifications (like 'likes') to keep young users engaged.

The companies previously argued under the 1990s Communications Decency Act that they are immune from liability for user-generated content, but the judge ruled that negligence and personal injury claims based on app design are still valid.
The judge emphasized that CEO testimony is crucial to assess the companies’ knowledge of harm and their failure to take preventive action.
Lawyers representing young users and families believe the trial will force social media executives to answer for the mental health harms caused by app design.
Meta and Snap have contested the claims, with similar litigation underway against TikTok and YouTube, indicating a broader industry-wide legal challenge.
Zuckerberg previously stated there was no causal link between social media use and youth mental health issues, but the trial challenges that position.
Instagram launched teen accounts with content screening and parental controls in response to public and legal pressure, showing a shift in platform design.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Meta Platforms, is required to testify in a landmark trial in Los Angeles County Superior Court over claims that social media platforms, including Meta-owned Instagram and Snap-owned Snapchat, have designed addictive features that harm youth mental health. The trial, expected in January 2025, consolidates hundreds of claims from parents and school districts alleging inadequate parental controls and harmful notification systems like 'likes.' Judge Carolyn Kuhl rejected Meta’s argument that in-person testimony was unnecessary, stating that CEO testimony is essential to assess knowledge of harm and failure to act. The companies previously relied on a 1990s law to avoid liability for user content, but the judge ruled that claims of negligence and personal injury stemming from app design remain valid. This case is part of a broader trend of legal pressure on social media companies following growing public concern over the mental health impacts of social media on young people, with similar litigation involving TikTok and YouTube. Meta and Snap have contested the claims, but the court’s decision emphasizes accountability at the executive level, with the expectation that the testimony will reveal whether the companies acted negligently despite being aware of risks.
title: Zuckerberg to testify in landmark social media trial
